017package de.mnl.osgi.lf4osgi.core;
018
019import java.util.Map;
020import java.util.Optional;
021import java.util.concurrent.ConcurrentHashMap;
022import java.util.function.Function;
023import org.osgi.framework.Bundle;
024import org.osgi.framework.BundleEvent;
025import org.osgi.framework.BundleListener;
026import org.osgi.framework.FrameworkUtil;
027
028/**
029 * A manager for groups of loggers associated with a bundle. A Logger 
030 * group for a given bundle is automatically discarded when the 
031 * associated bundle is uninstalled.
032 *
033 * @param <T> the logger group type
034 */
035public class LoggerCatalogue<T> {
036
037    private static final ContextHelper CTX_HLPR = new ContextHelper();
038
039    private boolean listenerInstalled;
040    private final Map<Bundle, T> groups = new ConcurrentHashMap<>();
041    private final Function<Bundle, T> groupSupplier;
042
043    /**
044     * Instantiates a new logger catalogue.
045     *
046     * @param groupSupplier the supplier for new logger groups
047     */
048    public LoggerCatalogue(Function<Bundle, T> groupSupplier) {
049        super();
050        this.groupSupplier = groupSupplier;
051        /*
052         * This may be invoked from from anywhere, even a static context.
053         * Therefore, it might not be possible to register the listener
054         * immediately.
055         */
056        checkListener();
057    }
058
059    private void checkListener() {
060        if (listenerInstalled) {
061            return;
062        }
063        Optional.ofNullable(FrameworkUtil.getBundle(groupSupplier.getClass()))
064            .map(Bundle::getBundleContext).ifPresent(ctx -> {
065                ctx.addBundleListener(new BundleListener() {
066                    @Override
067                    public void bundleChanged(BundleEvent event) {
068                        if (event.getType() == BundleEvent.UNINSTALLED) {
069                            groups.remove(event.getBundle());
070                        }
071                    }
072                });
073                listenerInstalled = true;
074                // This is unlikely to ever happen, but as this is delayed...
075                for (Bundle bdl : groups.keySet()) {
076                    if ((bdl.getState() & Bundle.UNINSTALLED) != 0) {
077                        groups.remove(bdl);
078                    }
079                }
080            });
081    }
082
083    /**
084     * Find the class that attempts to get a logger. This is done 
085     * by searching through the current call stack for the invocation 
086     * of the {@code getLogger} method of the class that provides 
087     * the loggers (the {@code providingClass}). The next frame in 
088     * the call stack then reveals the name of the class that 
089     * requests the logger.
090     *
091     * @param providingClass the providing class
092     * @return the optional
093     */
094    private static Optional<Class<?>>
095            findRequestingClass(String providingClass) {
096        StackTraceElement[] stackTrace = new Throwable().getStackTrace();
097        for (int i = 2; i < stackTrace.length; i++) {
098            StackTraceElement ste = stackTrace[i];
099            if (ste.getClassName().equals(providingClass)
100                && ste.getMethodName().equals("getLogger")) {
101                Class<?>[] classes = CTX_HLPR.getClassContext();
102                // getClassContext() adds one level, so the
103                // call of getLogger (in classes) should be at i+1.
104                i += 1;
105                // But... from the JavaDoc: "Some virtual machines may, under
106                // some circumstances, omit one or more stack frames
107                // from the stack trace." So let's make sure that we
108                // are really there.
109                while (!classes[i].getName().equals(providingClass)) {
110                    i += 1; // NOPMD
111                }
112                // Next one should now be the caller of getLogger. But
113                // in some libraries, getLogger calls "itself", e.g.
114                // getLogger(Class<?>) calls getLogger(String), proceed
115                // until we're out of this
116                while (classes[i].getName().equals(providingClass)) {
117                    i += 1; // NOPMD
118                }
119                return Optional.of(classes[i]);
120            }
121        }
122        return Optional.empty();
123    }
124
125    /**
126     * Find the bundle that contains the class that wants to get
127     * a logger, using the current call stack. 
128     * <P>
129     * The bundle is determined from the class that invoked 
130     * {@code getLogger}, which&mdash;in turn&mdash;is searched for in 
131     * the call stack as caller of the {@code getLogger} method of the 
132     * class that provides the loggers from the users point of view.
133     *
134     * @param providingClass the providing class
135     * @return the bundle
136     */
137    public static Optional<Bundle> findBundle(String providingClass) {
138        return findRequestingClass(providingClass)
139            .map(cls -> FrameworkUtil.getBundle(cls));
140    }
141
142    /**
143     * Returns the logger group for the given bundle.
144     *
145     * @param bundle the bundle
146     * @return the logger group
147     */
148    public T getLoggerGoup(Bundle bundle) {
149        checkListener();
150        return groups.computeIfAbsent(bundle, b -> groupSupplier.apply(b));
151    }
152
153    /**
154     * The Class ContextHelper.
155     */
156    private static class ContextHelper extends SecurityManager {
157        @Override
158        @SuppressWarnings("PMD.UselessOverridingMethod")
159        public Class<?>[] getClassContext() {
160            return super.getClassContext();
161        }
162    }
163}
